awd_titl_txt: ATD: Collaborative Research: Extremal Dependence and Change-Point Detection Methods for High-Dimensional Data Streams with Applications to Network Cybersecurity
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is motivated by the need to develop advanced network monitoring tools coupled with automated statistical methods for the quick detection of Internet traffic anomalies due to ongoing attacks or impending cybersecurity threats. Emphasis is placed on detecting cybersecurity threats such as highly distributed malware infections, which can launch coordinated and crippling distributed denial of service attacks on the nation's Internet infrastructure.  This will be achieved through a study of the so-called darknet traffic data. Malicious actors in the network systematically probe the Internet space for vulnerable or misconfigured devices. In doing so, they automatically send data to the entire Internet address space, which includes the space of unused Internet addresses. This destined-to-nowhere traffic is indicative of malware infection attempts or stealthy vulnerability scanning.  The investigators aim to develop and deploy specialized tools that allow cyber-security analysts to efficiently analyze darknet traffic data. The research involves a team of computer engineers and statisticians, who will work closely together to implement a prototype system for detecting as well as mapping and identifying world-wide malicious activity in the Internet. The project will create and communicate to the public a set of simple-to-interpret risk indices that summarize the current darknet threat activity.  This effort will potentially enable the prevention and mitigation of cybersecurity network traffic threats.

Understanding Internet threats, which continue to evolve due to the dynamic nature of Internet actors and the rapid expansion of the Internet of Things ecosystem, requires adequate data at fine-grained spatial and temporal scales. The project team has access to unique cyber-security data collected at Merit Network, Inc. that capture Internet-wide activity including network scanning, malware propagation, denial of service attacks, and network outages. This data consists of unsolicited Internet traffic destined to a routed but unused Internet address space, referred to as a darknet. This project will develop algorithmic and software infrastructure to collect and organize darknet data into high-dimensional, multivariate data streams, and will study statistical methods based on (i) extremal dependence, (ii) change-point detection, and/or (iii) high-dimensional sparse signal detection and recovery to inform the construction of Internet threat indices that quantify the risk of malicious scanning, degree of network vulnerability, risk of denial of service attacks, etc. Statistics of extremes in high-dimensional setting is a challenging problem since it requires the modeling/estimation of an infinite-dimensional parameter---the spectral measure. Using multivariate regular variation, this project will study novel hyper-graphical models that quantify and provide interpretable abstractions for the simultaneous occurrence of extremes in high-dimensions. Using limit theory for maxima of dependent variables, the project team will address open theoretical problems on the characterization of extremal dependence hyper-graphs and sparse signal detection in high-dimension. This analysis will lead to the development of novel threat indices that exhibit spatial dependence that will be analyzed with fast, scalable change-point detection algorithms. The new change-point methodology is designed to achieve large computational gains vis-a-vis standard approaches without compromising statistical accuracy and would be a significant contribution to the analysis of large data streams.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The space of Internet addresses not assigned to any real devices, is referred to as the "Darknet" (not to be confused with the darkweb).  Internet traffic destined to the Darknet is inherently malicious.  It originates from either misconfigured devices or from malicious actors or botnets of infected computers that indiscriminately ``scan’’ the network for vulnerable machines. By studying the sources of Darknet traffic, its volume, and structure, one can obtain a unique and dynamic world-wide view of potential cybersecurity threats, network outages, censorship, and other anomalies in the Internet. The project team had access to a large Darknet, and the access and availability of such unique and high-impact data has motivated the methodological and theoretical developments of the NSF-funded project.

The contributions of this project are numerous.  One key outcome of the current project is the development of statistical methodology and software tools for the access, visualization, and analysis of high-dimensional streams of Darknet traffic data. This was achieved in close collaboration of the co-PIs.  Specifically, a suite of interactive web-applications have been developed which access a large database of Darknet traffic.  These tools and data have already been used by many network researchers and collaborators.  The development of these tools involved a large team of undergraduate, master and doctoral students under the supervision of the co-PIs. The students have worked on problems that lie at the intersection of statistics, data science, software and database engineering, and interactive data visualizations. They had the opportunity to apply concepts learned in a classroom setting into practical problems using real-world, high-dimensional data obtained from the Darknet.  The figures in the report illustrate the developed statistical software tools. They can quantify and visualize anomalies in the Internet ranging from malicious scanning originating from malware-infected botnets to Internet outages due to natural disasters or censorship.

Another major contribution of the NSF-funded research is the solution of a fundamental theoretical problem.  Namely, this is the problem of the exact recovery of the support of a high-dimensional signal observed in additive noise. When the signal is a sparse high-dimensional vector, one fundamental question is when can its support (the set of non-zero components) be identified from the data.  For example, if one observes the Internet traffic activity (per a period of time) for all 65,536 ports, then one has a very high-dimensional vector, in statistical genetics (Genome-Wide Association Studies), one considers the expressions of 10s of thousands of genes resulting in a high-dimensional vector, etc.  In such and many other settings, identifying anomalies can be associated with the statistical estimation of the support of a signal obscured with additive noise.  

Until recently, it was not known what are the precise conditions on the signal amplitude (as a function of its sparsity) which allow for the exact recovery of the support.  The doctoral student Zheng Gao in collaboration with the co-PI (Stoev) solved this open problem!  The solution was motivated by extreme value theory and the concentration of maxima phenomenon, which turned out to be the right theoretical tools tailored for the so-called exact support recovery.  More precisely, Zheng Gao discovered a new phase-transition result whereby if the signal magnitude is above a certain boundary (function of the signal support sparsity), then a certain class of thresholding estimators can recover the exact support of the signal with probability going to 1, as the dimension goes to infinity.  Conversely, if the signal magnitude is below that very same boundary, then no thresholding estimators are able to recover the support. The research also shows when these thresholding estimators are optimal and thus it shows that so-established phase-transition is a universal phenomenon valid for all estimators.  This research has established the precise theoretical limitations or difficulty of the exact support recovery problem.  Ultimately, this will have a fundamental and broad impact on all future methodological or theoretical studies of anomaly detection that can be formulated in terms of exact support recovery.

In simple terms, we now know when one can and when nobody can recover all needles in a haystack as the haystack and number of needles thrown into it grow to infinity.

These fundamental results motivated the coPI and his student to publish a research monograph, in the prestigious and peer-reviewed SpringerBriefs series in probability and mathematical statistics.  The book is largely the product of the NSF-funded research.
